text: Impaired fetal thymocyte development after efficient adenovirus - mediated inhibition of NF-kappa B activation .
We introduce a new experimental system combining adenovirus - mediated gene transfer and fetal thymic organ culture ( FTOC ) .

This system allowed us to efficiently express in developing thymocytes a mutant form of the NF-kappa B inhibitor <extra_id_0> I kappa B alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> mut-I kappa B <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) and to study the maturation defects occurring when NF-kappa B activation is inhibited during fetal development .

text: Fetal thymocytes infected with adenovirus containing mut-I kappa B were found to develop normally until the <extra_id_0> CD44 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - <extra_id_0> CD25 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + , <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - CD8 - double-negative stage , while production of more mature double-positive and single - positive populations was strongly decreased .
Proliferation , as measured by the percentage of cells in cycle appeared normal , as did rearrangement and expression of the <extra_id_0> TCR beta-chain <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .

text: However , apoptosis was much higher in FTOC infected with adenovirus containing mut-I kappa B than in FTOC infected with a control virus .
Taken together , these results suggest that NF-kappa B plays a crucial role in ensuring the differentiation and survival of thymocytes in the early stages of their development .
